reviewText: This limited edition DVD box set is a must buy for all Dragon Ball Z fans. The Dragon Boxes offer both the dubbed English verson with Japanese opening and ending songs, and of course the original Japanese version. Volume One has the first 42 episodes. All Dragon Boxes come with a hardcover booklet, and two DVD cases. On top of all of this, the box art is amazing, and looks great on your shelf. Again if you are a Dragon Ball fan, buy this before you can't!
summary: Best Dragon Ball Z Box Set.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I first heard the Dragon Box was coming to America, I thought it was some kind of lame joke. But it turns out that it is actually true. For those who don't know. The Dragon Box was released in Japan years ago which featured a true frame by frame restoration of the Dragon Ball Z anime. The original 16mm film was used to create the DVDs that were sold in Japan, so the original colors and frame alignment are being displayed correctly.One thing about the Japanese Dragon Box release was the price. It actually came in 2 seperate boxes, each containing one half of the series, which retailed for about 100,000 yen, or about $850 USD for each box. So for the Japanese release, you would spend over $1700 USD for the entire series. Also keep in mind there is no subtitles on the Japanese release as well, just Japanese language only. Instead of 2 boxes, FUNimation has decided to split the set in 7 seperate sets. This will make it easier to purchase the entire series at a much lower cost. For all 291 episodes of Dragon Ball Z in Dragon Box format, you could probably expect to pay around $400 as opposed to $1700 for the Japanese version.Now, thanks to FUNimation, the Dragon Boxes are coming to the US with subtitles and English audio options and most importantly, a FULLSCREEN aspect ratio. This definitely makes up for the much reviled "season sets" in which they tried to convince the public that it was in "widescreen" when in reality they actually cropped the footage resulting in substaintial loss of original footage.This release is not for everybody, if you are already satisfied with the orange brick season sets, then stick with them. But if you want to view Dragon Ball Z "the way it was meant to be seen," I highly recommend tbe Dragon Box sets to see this great series in its original broadcast form.
summary: FUNimation redeems itself for Orange Brick nonsense.

reviewText: To be blunt, I am a specific fan.  That meaning that as long as I already have the complete series of a tv show and it's uncut, why the FUDGE would I want to fork out 30, 40 sumthin' freakin' dollars for the same series that I ALREADY HAVE!!!!!!The problem with our society today is that most of them too easily "swallows the hookline" when it comes to show formats, DVD, & Video game releases.  A PRIME example is that most so called people don't care about what bonus features, Ocean Dub dialogue, or old VHS & DVD promos are NOT carried over to these "definitive" boxsets as long as they are "digitally remastered" and "properly transferred to widescreen".I am really FED UP with this!!!!!!!!!!! Every W.E. (World Entertainment) dvd set now features badly dubbed over music, I've wasted over 70 DOLLARS on Disney's badly releases of Darkwing Duck vol. 2, & Xmen: The Animated series vol. 1 and 2, and over 247 DOLLARS on (you guessed it) the "orange brick" boxsets of DBZ & their movies.So why am I supposed to take companies like Funimation seriously anymore (with no disrespect to their voice actors), when I came across the url website[...] after purchasing the "orange" & "silver tinned" bricks then realizing the harsh truth that Funimation has duped me & anyone else by constantly getting Christopher Sabat & others to advertise bald face LIES about the Bricks & Dragon Boxes being "definitive", PLEASE! I no longer believe the overrated hype!The worst part of this is, most people who post DVD reviews on sites like Amazon don't give a rat's crap about the most important essestials that are WHAT"S NOT INCLUDED!..... Why? I truly understand the neccessities of company income but Funimation, Disney, the WWE, & any and ALL companies & genres that are taking this cheap and degrading "cash-flow" routine to milk money out of innocent people should all be ashamed of theirselves.So as a future reference, I would appreciate it if companies would stop their greedish ways & for fans (especially on Amazon) to stop being so "sheepish" and take into account on how their innaccurately "positive reviews" are effecting us as a majority.  Also we need to spread this message so that others won't support these "definitive" sets that don't and won't include 1)a choice between viewing the Ocean Dub & Funimation dialogues, whether original or redub, 2)A choice to view any & all past openings & closing credits, 3)A choice to view ALL previous VHS & dvd extras/promos from previous releases, & to top the icing on the cake,....... 4) view any & ALL TOONAMI & cough.... Kids WB Promos of the Dragon Ball series in the respective (in all senses of the word), TRUE boxsets!!!!!!!!!!!!! There is YouTube, [...][...] [...], AMAZON, [...]& many other sites where we can petition to STOP all these bogus DVD releases so we can have TRUE collections!As a beloved wrestler used to put it "Well Enough IS Enough, and it's time for a change!".  Anyway I hope "THAT" review/insight was helpful to you all.  Keep the faith.-Bryant Out!
summary: This is pathetic! It is obvious that Funny-mation doesn't care about it's fans {anymore}.

reviewText: Finally, after 13 years of initially becoming a DBZ fan and clamoring for the series uncut without resorting to fan subs on VHS, it's delivered on DVD in the United States uncut, subbed, AND with good video quality (retaining grain and other film qualities). This is DBZ the way it's meant to be seen, and I can't wait to finally see the entire series, beginning to end, untainted. Keep it up, FUNimation; don't skimp out on any future Dragon Box volumes.The packaging is a delight as well. I wonder if it emulates the Japanese packaging, because the book's pages are ordered from right to left, as is the placement of the discs.There you go, a short review from one very happy customer. I refused to buy the previous season sets due to the horrible video quality. I'm one who cannot stand cropping, excessive DVNR, and severe contrast boosting. I'm glad FUNimation finally listened to the most extreme fans of DBZ and delivered what we've wanted all along.
summary: At long last

reviewText: The original Dragon Box 1 came with the Bardock TV Special (Movie), the episodes, tons of extras on disc, and an action figure. This doesn't have anything boxed with it besides the episodes.Not only that, but the superior American music score isn't included either. If you watched this on Toonami (I'm sure most of you have) you won't get the same experience. The new score was part of what made this show so popular in the US. The Japanese score was replaced because it was outdated and didn't fit the mood of the later, more action oriented episodes of the show. If you buy this, you will see what I mean. The same thing goes for the opening sequences. I'm not saying they should have completely shunned the original Japanese parts of the show, but it would have been nice if they included both. Especially since they didn't include the extras and had room for it on the discs. (Note: They didn't put these on Blu Ray so they could use the "lack of space" excuse)The only real reason to get this over the orange box sets is the picture quality. These new ones supposedly don't have the cropping that the other sets have, but it's unknown if that is wishful thinking on the part of the fans, or fact. For all we know, the episodes could have the same cut off parts as the orange sets. We will see.[Revamped]
summary: No movies, no extras, but priced higher than the orange DBZ box sets?

reviewText: Dragon Ball Z: Dragon Box One contains the first forty-two episodes of the series; these episodes cover the entirety of the Vegeta saga and the early episodes from the Namek saga.It's obvious that this set was being marketed to the "hardcore" Dragon Ball Z fans by some of the decisions that were made by FUNimation when they put this set together.  The default language for viewing is set to Japanese language with English subtitles, the title cards for the episodes use the Japanese titles for the episodes instead of the titles for the English dub, only the original Japanese music score is included, and the packaging and booklets use the original Japanese spelling for the characters' names instead of the alternate spellings that were used in the English dub.  In addition, the episodes are presented in a 4:3 aspect ratio, instead of the 16:9 cropping that was done for the nine "orange box" season sets.Dragon Box One comes with a 47-page hardcover book that has a right-to-left orientation.  The book begins with a brief overview of the first Dragon Ball series, character profiles, and an "Ultimate Character Relationship Chart."  The bulk of the book, however, is a section talking about the episodes that are included in the set.  The episode section of the book includes the Japanese titles for the episodes, a description for each episode, the original airdate for each episode, still images from the episodes, trivia, and a brief overview of the story that appears on each disc in the set.  The book concludes with a "fashion check" that comments on some of the outfits that are seen in the episodes in this set and line art drawings of some of the characters.A drawback to this set is the fact that there are no special features included on any of the discs; FUNimation didn't even bother to put on the textless opening and closing or any trailers.  I would guess that the company felt that since the book was included, that there really wasn't a need for special features on the discs.  Also, I was disappointed to see that the "Marathon Feature" from the "orange brick" season sets wasn't included, because it made it easier to watch the episodes back-to-back on each disc.  On the plus side, if you watch the Japanese language versions of the episodes, you get to see the next episode previews at the end of each episode; these had not been included in the original "orange brick" season box sets that FUNimation had released.I would recommend Dragon Ball Z: Dragon Box One to fans of Dragon Ball Z who want to have a better version of the episodes than what appears on the "orange boxes" and don't want to wait for FUNimation to make it through the Blu-ray releases, which only seem to include thirteen episodes on each Blu-ray set.I wrote this review after watching a copy of this DVD box set that my husband and I purchased.
summary: The first of the seven Dragon Boxes released in the United States

reviewText: Compared with modern releases of Anime, Dragonball Z may initially seem to be less daring and less on the cutting edge.  This series takes a little while to grow on you. But it's worth watching and hanging on through the slower rough spots in the first season.  By the time you start on Dragon Box Two, you'll realize that this series takes on some very hardcore issues in very dramatic style. The enemies that Goku and his son Gohan face are truly evil villains, mass-murdering torturing sick-minded people who wipe out entire civilizations for their own amusement or personal gain.  There is never any doubt who the good guys are in this series, they are the ones sacrificing their own lives to save their world.The series has a lot of light hearted moments and humor, which is good, because that offsets the very dark and very disturbing nature of many of the dramatically evil and violent events that occur. Seriously, there is some very nasty and horrifying stuff that occurs in this series.  This long running anime series touches upon various genres including science fiction, horror, revenge and humor.Because of some very nasty scenes in the series, I recommend no one younger than a teenager for this material.  The box rating is PG, but I would bump that rating up a level to at least PG-13. In fact some of the scenes deserve an "R" rating for the violence.The disks worked flawlessly.  The video and audio were perfect. I also liked the cases the disks come in.  The Dragon Boxes are packed with two hard-shell disk cases with three disks in each. Each disk contains seven episodes. The disks were easy to remove and put back in the case, and each Dragon Box comes with a hardcover book containing great images of the characters and descriptions of each episode.- Mike Silverman
summary: ONE OF THE BEST CLASSIC ANIME SERIES
Title: N/A

reviewText: I own all nine DBZ orange boxsets and I wanted to know what the excitement was all about with the Dragon Boxes.Actually, I think before they started releasing the Dragon Boxes, I did some calculations of my own. I know with most of the DVDs from the boxsets some have 3 or 5 or 6 episodes and I thought if you put 7 episodes a disc on 6 discs and keep doing that until you reach the last episode, just how many season boxsets would you save. The answer I found was you would save 2 whole season boxsets.If they were ever going to release the Dragonball series into Dragonboxes they would be only able to release 4 of them instead of the 5 season Dragonball boxsets.  So they would save one whole season boxset.My calculations are, if they put 40 episodes on 6 discs for the first 3 Dragonboxes (equals 120 episodes) that will leave 33 episodes for Dragonbox 4.What was different with the Dragon Boxes compared to the boxsets is the Dragon Boxes are shown in full original un-cropped 4:3 format. So much more image can be viewed in 4:3, I had to question myself whether the boxsets actually cropped the image and sadly yes they did.I believe Dragonball Z is meant to be viewed in 16:9. Every shot, every angle suits the widescreen experience. I'd wonder if the cropping is optional.The picture quality in the Dragon Boxes is grainy and not at all clear and sharp as the digitally re-mastered DBZ boxsets.I noticed in some dark shots in the Dragon Box episodes you could see things, which can't be seen in the boxsets. For example, when Goku runs up the dark stairway to reach Snake Way, you can literally see the steps and when he sees the light at the top, you can see the woodwork in King Yemma's desk drawer (To view these images please see customer images in Dragonbox Season 1).I still prefer the animation to be digitally re-mastered but as long as they don't crop it and not making some of the dark parts so dark that not much can be seen.I am a huge fan of the Bruce Falconer's music but the Japanese music, they repeat a lot of the music and there isn't a great deal of variety. But as you progress through the series, you hear different music.I know with the American music they do repeat the music here and there but there is a lot more music to choose from. Some parts in the episodes there isn't music at all and you can really hear what the characters are saying, rather than having their voices drowned out by the American music. I did notice a few music tracks from Dragonball from the Japanese music.What I like about the Dragonbox booklet is that it feels much more like a hard covered book unlike DBZ boxset booklet, which feels a lot less sturdy. This means the DBZ boxset booklet will damage easily compared to the Dragonbox booklet.This is the same with the actual boxset and Dragonball where the DVD cases or DVDs are kept.I do like the summary on the back of the DBZ boxset, which details part of the DBZ story up to that point.Although in the Dragonbox booklet, you get thorough information on the episodes and when they aired, characters interaction with other characters (looks like a family tree), character designs and a timeline on what the Dragonball Z series made their mark in the world.I believe the Dragon Box are for fans who want to stay close to the original with the music and 4:3 format. Even I go back to the Dragon Boxes over the boxsets.
summary: Dragon Box VS DBZ Boxset

reviewText: Like me if you spent the last 2 1/2 years collecting the re-mastered seasons collecting Dragon Ball Z you are likely done by now and most likely becoming focused on the releases of the Complete seasons of Dragon Ball that will begin release in September. This is one I am not going looking forward to at all. Don't plunk down double the price just for a couple more episodes of what will likely turn out to be who knows how many more boxed sets of the same show that was released in the complete seasons. Keep in mind that this set will have a lower audio quality and not feature and changes to the English dub. Big deal if these episodes are the 1:33:1 aspect ratio which doesn't really matter at all to me and many other people. If there was to be another release to be concerned about it would be an English Dub of the Re-mastered Dragon Ball Kai.(Will it happen? don't know.) Besides when this is all said and done, maybe you can go and spend 4 times the price of the complete seasons for Blu-Ray versions of the series if that happens. Save you money. Here is the Amazon link to the much cheaper re-mastered season 1.Dragon Ball Z - Season One (Vegeta Saga)

reviewText: Almost all DBZ fans grew up watching this amazing series on Cartoon Network. The score was amazing, and the screaming of Vegeta legendary. When the orange boxsets appeared i immediatly bought them only to find out that there was a redicoules audio on it and some gay sounding Vegeta. It was horrible, i sold them right away.Now they're bringing out the Dragonbox sets, but again with the redicoules Japanese audio. This is an action series people, that gay Japanese score belongs with a program for four year olds not with a series for teenagers. I found the Dragonball Z with the original audio on a site promoting Anime series. It has the original score in the first 53 episodes. After that some sound bits change but the overall score is like we remember it from cartoon network. It costs a pretty penny, but you get the entire series in one buy. Plus they are region free so they are guaranteed to play. Still i'm not a 100% satisfied. I hope Funimation will release these dragon boxes with the original English audio and the Bruce Foulckner score. Let's hope they do that soon.
summary: Where's the audio we now and love?

reviewText: This set includes 42 uncut episodes, bringing Dragon Ball Z to the North American market in what is truly the "way it was meant to be see" and as originally intended.The remastering job is nothing short of beautifully astounding. Cell jitter is all but non-existent. The tape marks and film damage are minimized or removed completely.And most importantly, this release gives us "everything" a fan has dreamed of since the beginning - complete and original openings in the correct order and locations, uncut content for every part of the show, full on end credits with original music and... next episode previews! This last bit is really important, as before the Dragon Box releases, these were omitted. FUNimation stated long ago this was due to the Japanese licensing company (Toei) not handing over versions with the original Japanese language. This has been corrected.Despite cramming 6-7 episodes on a disc, the video quality is honestly top tier. If you pixel peep you will see instances of compression blocking once in a great while, but none of this is visible in action. This is what had me scared about this release at first, though now I'm happy to report that it looks great.The only issue with video is that the North American release is slightly brighter than the Japanese release. This is due to the difference in the black levels of the NTSC standards between the US and Japan. This can be counteracted by simply turning the brightness down a little. Also, this release is ever so slightly differently aligned in the frame over the Japanese release. This is never enough to really be an true issue though.The audio, while not as high a bit rate as the Japanese release, is as flawless as can be expected. This is the Japanese audio track I am speaking of. It should be noted that DBZ was originally recorded in mono. The Japanese Dragon Box did this in stereo by simply duplicating the mono audio on both channels. To save on space I assume, FUNimation has instead opted to put single track mono in (you won't notice a difference since your system should duplicate it automatically). The only audible concern I have is that sometimes it has some distortion in the audio, BUT it should be noted this is typical of a mono soundtrack and not something that can be "fixed."The English audio included is the 5.1 mix that uses the Japanese music and effects. If you are a fan of the re-envisioned version of the English language tracks, you will be disappointed.The box itself is well made, the artwork is well chosen and the book that is included is actually a worthy read. There are some minor inconsistencies that emulate what I would loving call "Engrish" that was included in the original Japanese book (or so I've read), but it is easily over looked.The day fandom never thought would arrive, has. First DBZ is released truly uncut using the mythical Dragon Box video, but we've also witnessed a rebirth of classic Anime being released in the ensuing years (Fist of the North Star TV, Galaxy Express, etc).It's a great time to be a fan.
summary: Best video quality available in the US on DVD
